ROS 2 Fundamentals

ROS 2 (Robot Operating System 2) uses a DDS (Data Distribution Service)-based communication architecture that provides reliable, real-time communication between robot components. Unlike ROS 1's centralized master architecture, ROS 2 uses a distributed system where nodes can discover each other automatically.

Key Components

  • Nodes: Processes that perform computation. Nodes are the fundamental building blocks of a ROS 2 program.
  • Topics: Named buses over which nodes exchange messages. Topics use a publisher-subscriber communication model.
  • Services: Synchronous request-response communication pattern between nodes.
  • Actions: Asynchronous communication pattern for long-running tasks with feedback.

Our Implementation

In our humanoid robotics implementation, we created several nodes:

  • joint_publisher_node: Publishes joint state information
  • joint_subscriber_node: Subscribes to joint commands
  • gesture_service_node: Provides gesture execution services
  • movement_action_node: Handles robot movement actions
# Example publisher from our implementation
publisher_ = self.create_publisher(JointState, 'joint_states', 10)

# Example subscriber from our implementation
subscription = self.create_subscription(
    JointCommand,
    'joint_command',
    self.joint_command_callback,
    10
)

Python Integration with ROS 2

We use the rclpy library, which is the Python client library for ROS 2, to create ROS 2 nodes and interact with the robot system.

Basic Node Structure

import rclpy
from rclpy.node import Node

class MyNode(Node):
    def __init__(self):
        super().__init__('node_name')
        # Initialize publishers, subscribers, services, etc.

def main(args=None):
    rclpy.init(args=args)
    node = MyNode()

    try:
        rclpy.spin(node)
    except KeyboardInterrupt:
        pass
    finally:
        node.destroy_node()
        rclpy.shutdown()

if __name__ == '__main__':
    main()

Joint State Publisher Example

class JointPublisherNode(Node):
    def __init__(self):
        super().__init__('joint_publisher_node')

        # Create publisher for joint states
        self.publisher_ = self.create_publisher(JointState, 'joint_states', 10)

        # Timer to publish at regular intervals
        timer_period = 0.02  # seconds
        self.timer = self.create_timer(timer_period, self.timer_callback)

    def timer_callback(self):
        msg = JointState()
        msg.header = Header()
        msg.header.stamp = self.get_clock().now().to_msg()
        msg.header.frame_id = 'base_link'

        # Set joint names and positions
        msg.name = self.joint_names
        msg.position = self.joint_positions
        msg.velocity = self.joint_velocities
        msg.effort = self.joint_efforts

        self.publisher_.publish(msg)

Robot Description & URDF

URDF (Unified Robot Description Format) is an XML format used in ROS to describe robot models. It defines the physical and visual properties of a robot, including links, joints, visual and collision properties, inertial properties, and sensors.

Basic URDF Structure

<?xml version="1.0"?>
<robot name="robot_name">
  <!-- Links -->
  <link name="link_name">
    <visual>
      <geometry>
        <!-- Shape definition -->
      </geometry>
      <material name="material_name">
        <color rgba="1 0 0 1"/> <!-- Red color -->
      </material>
    </visual>
    <collision>
      <geometry>
        <!-- Shape definition for collision detection -->
      </geometry>
    </collision>
    <inertial>
      <mass value="1"/>
      <inertia ixx="0.01" ixy="0" ixz="0" iyy="0.01" iyz="0" izz="0.01"/>
    </inertial>
  </link>

  <!-- Joints -->
  <joint name="joint_name" type="joint_type">
    <parent link="parent_link_name"/>
    <child link="child_link_name"/>
    <origin xyz="0 0 0" rpy="0 0 0"/>
    <axis xyz="0 0 1"/>
    <limit lower="-1.57" upper="1.57" effort="100" velocity="1"/>
  </joint>
</robot>

Our Humanoid Robot Model

Our implementation includes a complete humanoid robot with 8 degrees of freedom:

  • Links: base_link, torso, head, arms (left and right), legs (left and right)
  • Joints: 4 in arms (2 per arm), 4 in legs (2 per leg)
  • Sensors: Camera on head, IMU in torso

Joint Configuration Example

<joint name="left_shoulder_pitch" type="revolute">
  <parent link="torso"/>
  <child link="left_upper_arm"/>
  <origin xyz="0.1 0 0.1"/>
  <axis xyz="0 1 0"/>
  <limit lower="-1.57" upper="1.57" effort="100" velocity="1"/>
</joint>

Building and Running

# Source ROS 2 environment
source /opt/ros/humble/setup.bash

# Navigate to workspace
cd ~/ros2_ws

# Build packages
colcon build

# Source the workspace
source install/setup.bash

# Run a single node
ros2 run robot_control_nodes joint_publisher_node

# Run with launch file
ros2 launch robot_control_nodes joint_control.launch.py

Custom Message Definition

# JointCommand.msg
string joint_name
float64 target_position
float64 target_velocity
float64 effort

Spec-Driven Development for Robotics

Spec-Driven Development is a methodology where comprehensive specifications are created before any implementation begins. This approach ensures clear understanding of requirements before coding, reduces rework and refactoring, and provides better project planning.

The SDD Process

  1. Feature Specification (spec.md): Defines what needs to be built
  2. Implementation Plan (plan.md): Details how the feature will be built
  3. Task List (tasks.md): Breaks down implementation into executable steps

Example Feature Specification

# Feature Specification: ROS 2 Robotics Module

## User Scenarios & Testing *(mandatory)*

### User Story 1 - ROS 2 Node Development (Priority: P1)
As a student learning robotics, I want to create a Python node that publishes joint angles to a humanoid robot, so that I can understand how to control robot movements through ROS 2 communication.

**Why this priority**: This is the foundational skill needed to control robot behavior and is required for all other exercises in the module.

**Independent Test**: Can be fully tested by running the Python node and verifying that joint angle messages are published to the correct ROS topic, and that the robot simulator responds appropriately.

**Acceptance Scenarios**:
1. **Given** a running ROS 2 environment with a simulated humanoid robot, **When** I run my Python node that publishes joint angles, **Then** the robot's joints move according to the published angle values

Benefits in Robotics Development

  • Clear Requirements Definition: Prevents integration issues and misunderstandings
  • Architecture Decisions: Helps make important decisions upfront
  • Testing Strategy: Naturally leads to clear testing strategies
  • Traceability: Maintains clear path from requirements to implementation

Best Practices for SDD in Robotics

  • Start with User Value: Always begin specifications with user needs and value
  • Make it Testable: Ensure all requirements can be verified
  • Iterate and Refine: Specifications should evolve based on learning
  • Involve Stakeholders: Get input from all relevant parties
  • Document Decisions: Keep records of design decisions and trade-offs
